name: The Age of Exploration and Colonialism

chapters.name: The Portuguese Push South: Prince Henry and the African Coast
topics: Why did Prince Henry the Navigator fund decades of expeditions down the African coast starting in 1415, and what specific economic and religious motives drove him?
How did the Portuguese capture of Ceuta in 1415 set the template for European colonial violence for the next five centuries?
What navigational technologies — the caravel, the astrolabe, the volta do mar technique — gave Portugal an edge over every other European power?
How did Bartolomeu Dias rounding the Cape of Good Hope in 1488 change European understanding of world geography overnight?
Why did Portugal establish fortified trading posts (feitorias) rather than territorial colonies in West Africa, and how did this model shape the early slave trade?
What role did the papal bulls Dum Diversas (1452) and Romanus Pontifex (1455) play in giving Portugal a religious license to enslave non-Christians?

chapters.name: Columbus, the Taino, and the Spanish Claim to the New World
topics: What specific miscalculations about the Earth's circumference led Columbus to believe he could reach Asia by sailing west, and why did most educated Europeans know he was wrong?
How did Columbus describe the Taino people in his journal on October 12, 1492, and how did those first impressions predict the genocide that followed?
What were the terms of the Capitulations of Santa Fe, and how did they make Columbus both an explorer and a potential colonial overlord?
How did the Treaty of Tordesillas in 1494 divide the entire non-Christian world between Spain and Portugal with a line on a map?
Why did the Taino population of Hispaniola collapse from an estimated 250,000 to fewer than 500 within fifty years of Columbus's arrival?
How did the encomienda system function as legal forced labor, and why did Bartolome de Las Casas call it worse than outright slavery?

chapters.name: The Conquest of the Aztec and Inca Empires
topics: How did Hernan Cortes conquer the Aztec Empire with fewer than 600 soldiers, and what role did indigenous allies like the Tlaxcalans play in Tenochtitlan's fall in 1521?
What was the Noche Triste of June 30, 1520, and how close did the Aztecs come to destroying Cortes's entire expedition?
How did Francisco Pizarro exploit the Inca civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar to capture an emperor and ransom him for a room filled with gold?
Why did European diseases — smallpox, measles, typhus — kill an estimated 90% of indigenous Americans, and how did this demographic catastrophe enable conquest?
What happened to the vast gold and silver wealth seized from the Aztec and Inca, and how did it fuel inflation across Europe (the 'Price Revolution')?
How did the destruction of Tenochtitlan's aqueducts, temples, and libraries represent a deliberate erasure of indigenous knowledge and civilization?

chapters.name: The Atlantic Slave Trade: Scale, Mechanism, and Human Cost
topics: How many Africans were forcibly transported across the Atlantic between 1500 and 1870, and why do estimates range from 10 to 15 million survivors with millions more dying en route?
How did the 'triangular trade' work — what specific goods moved on each leg between Europe, Africa, and the Americas?
What were conditions like during the Middle Passage, and why did mortality rates on slave ships average 15-20% even when slavers had financial incentives to keep captives alive?
How did African kingdoms like Dahomey and Asante become active participants in the slave trade, and what internal political pressures drove their involvement?
Why did sugar plantations in the Caribbean and Brazil consume enslaved laborers at such catastrophic rates that they required constant new imports?
How did the Zong massacre of 1781 — where 132 enslaved people were thrown overboard for insurance money — expose the legal framework that treated human beings as cargo?

chapters.name: Spain's American Empire: Silver, Missions, and the Caste System
topics: How did the silver mines of Potosi (modern Bolivia) become the engine of the global economy, producing an estimated 60% of the world's silver by 1600?
What was the mita labor system, and how did the Spanish adapt Inca forced-labor practices to work thousands of indigenous miners to death?
How did the sistema de castas classify people by racial mixture (mestizo, mulato, zambo), and what legal rights and restrictions attached to each category?
Why did Spanish missionaries destroy thousands of indigenous codices, quipus, and sacred sites while simultaneously recording indigenous languages and customs?
How did the Manila Galleon trade route (1565-1815) connect Spanish America to China, creating the first truly global trading network?
What drove the series of indigenous revolts — from the Mixtion War (1540) to the Tupac Amaru II rebellion (1780) — and why did Spain suppress each one with extreme violence?

chapters.name: The Portuguese Seaborne Empire: From Brazil to Macau
topics: How did Portugal — a country of barely one million people — build a trading empire spanning four continents by 1550?
What was the Estado da India, and how did Afonso de Albuquerque's capture of Goa (1510), Malacca (1511), and Hormuz (1515) give Portugal control of Indian Ocean trade routes?
Why did Portugal import an estimated 4.9 million enslaved Africans to Brazil — more than any other colony in the Americas — and how did sugar drive that demand?
How did Portuguese Jesuits gain access to the Chinese and Japanese courts, and why did Japan eventually expel all Europeans in 1639?
What was the Treaty of Madrid (1750) and how did it reshape the border between Spanish and Portuguese territory in South America?
Why did Portugal's empire decline so rapidly after 1600, and how did the Dutch systematically seize Portuguese trading posts across Asia?

chapters.name: The Dutch Golden Age and Commercial Colonialism
topics: How did the Dutch East India Company (VOC), founded in 1602, become the world's first multinational corporation with the power to wage war, negotiate treaties, and mint coins?
What was the Banda Islands massacre of 1621, where the Dutch killed or deported virtually the entire population to monopolize the nutmeg trade?
How did the Dutch West India Company's operations differ from the VOC, and why did its control of the Atlantic slave trade become its most profitable business?
Why did the Dutch Republic — a nation built on religious tolerance — become one of the most ruthless colonial powers in Southeast Asia?
How did the Dutch create the Cape Colony in 1652 as a supply station, and how did this foothold eventually lead to apartheid South Africa?
What was the 'tulip mania' of 1637, and what does it reveal about the speculative financial culture that colonialism created in the Netherlands?

chapters.name: The British and French Struggle for North America
topics: How did the Jamestown colony of 1607 nearly fail completely, and what role did John Rolfe's tobacco cultivation play in making Virginia profitable through enslaved labor?
Why did the French pursue a fundamentally different colonial model in North America — fur trading and indigenous alliances rather than mass settlement?
How did the Seven Years' War (1756-1763) become the first true 'world war,' fought on five continents, and why did Britain's victory doom French North America?
What was the impact of the 1763 Royal Proclamation that drew a line along the Appalachian Mountains and forbade colonial settlement westward — and why did colonists ignore it?
How did diseases introduced by European settlers devastate the Haudenosaunee, Algonquin, and other First Nations, with some communities losing 75-90% of their populations?
Why did Benjamin Franklin's Albany Plan of Union (1754) fail, and what does its failure reveal about colonial rivalries that would later complicate the American Revolution?

chapters.name: The East India Companies: When Corporations Ruled Nations
topics: How did the British East India Company go from a trading firm chartered in 1600 to governing 200 million people across the Indian subcontinent by the 1850s?
What was the Battle of Plassey (1757), and how did Robert Clive's bribery of Mir Jafar transform the EIC from merchant to sovereign power in Bengal?
How did the EIC's forced cultivation of opium in India and its sale to China lead directly to the Opium Wars of 1839-1842 and 1856-1860?
Why did the Bengal famine of 1770 kill an estimated 10 million people, and what role did EIC taxation and crop diversion policies play?
How did the Dutch VOC's 'spice monopoly' strategy — including destroying crops to keep prices high — devastate the economies of Indonesia's Maluku Islands?
What finally ended corporate colonial rule, and why did the British government take direct control of India only after the 1857 Sepoy Mutiny?

chapters.name: Mercantilism: The Economic Engine of Empire
topics: What was mercantilism, and why did European governments believe that colonies existed solely to enrich the mother country?
How did Britain's Navigation Acts (1651-1696) force American colonists to trade exclusively with England, and why did widespread smuggling undermine the system?
What was the asiento system, and how did the British South Sea Company win the contract to supply enslaved Africans to Spanish America?
How did plantation monocultures — sugar in the Caribbean, tobacco in Virginia, cotton in the Deep South — create wealth for Europe while destroying colonial ecosystems and enslaved populations?
Why did Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations (1776) argue that mercantilism was economically irrational, and how did his ideas eventually undermine the justification for colonial monopolies?
How did mercantilist competition between Britain, France, and the Netherlands trigger colonial wars that reshaped the global map between 1600 and 1800?

chapters.name: Resistance, Rebellion, and the Haitian Revolution
topics: How did the Haitian Revolution (1791-1804) become the only successful large-scale slave revolt in history, and why did Toussaint Louverture's army defeat both French and British forces?
What was the Maroon resistance model, and how did escaped enslaved communities in Jamaica, Suriname, and Brazil sustain independent societies for generations?
Why did Tupac Amaru II's 1780 rebellion in Peru mobilize 60,000 indigenous people, and how did Spain's brutal suppression include banning indigenous clothing and language?
How did the Stono Rebellion of 1739 in South Carolina lead to harsher slave codes rather than any reconsideration of the institution?
What role did Queen Nzinga of Ndongo play in resisting Portuguese slave raids in Angola for over 30 years in the 1600s?
Why did the Haitian Revolution terrify slaveholding societies across the Americas, and how did it directly influence both the abolition movement and the tightening of slave laws?

chapters.name: The Legacy: How Colonialism Shaped the Modern World
topics: How did the colonial extraction of wealth from Asia, Africa, and the Americas finance the Industrial Revolution in Europe?
Why do the borders drawn by European colonizers — often ignoring ethnic, linguistic, and geographic realities — continue to cause conflict in Africa and the Middle East today?
What is the 'development of underdevelopment' thesis, and how does it explain why former colonies remain among the world's poorest nations?
How did colonial racial hierarchies — the sistema de castas, South African racial classifications, the 'one-drop rule' in the US — create social structures that persist centuries later?
Why have calls for colonial reparations intensified in the 21st century, and what specific calculations have been proposed (such as India's demand for British reparations)?
How did the colonial encounter permanently alter global ecology through the 'Columbian Exchange' of plants, animals, and diseases between the Old and New Worlds?
